title: Paralysis
data:
**Paralysis** is a magically-induced inability to move. Depending on the length and cause, paralysis can be quite dangerous, as monsters may get many free turns. However, a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") that was right next to you as you sleep may be able to guard you and therefore save your life against attacking monsters.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Causes](#Causes)
- [2 Prevention](#Prevention)
- [3 Monster paralysis](#Monster_paralysis)
- [4 Helplessness](#Helplessness)
- [5 References](#References)
- [6 See also](#See_also)

## Causes

- Attacking a [floating eye](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye"). If you can see it and your hit does not kill it, there is a 2/3 chance that you will be paralyzed for a large number of turns (usually d70).[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)
- Attacking or being attacked by a [gelatinous cube](/wiki/Gelatinous_cube "Gelatinous cube"). This paralysis does not last as long.
- Being attacked by a [shade](/wiki/Shade "Shade"), [ghoul](/wiki/Ghoul "Ghoul"), [guardian naga](/wiki/Guardian_naga "Guardian naga") or [Yeenoghu](/wiki/Yeenoghu "Yeenoghu"). This attack is affected by [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation").
- Being hit by a thrown or wielded [potion of paralysis](/wiki/Potion_of_paralysis "Potion of paralysis"). This will paralyze you for 1-5 turns.
- Drinking a [potion of paralysis](/wiki/Potion_of_paralysis "Potion of paralysis"). This will paralyze you for 13-46 turns depending on BUC.
- Being attacked by the [clerical spell](/wiki/Monster_spell#Clerical_Spells "Monster spell") [paralyze](/wiki/Paralyze_\(monster_spell\) "Paralyze (monster spell)").
- Being hit by [Magicbane](/wiki/Magicbane "Magicbane") (one of the random effects).

## Prevention

Wearing a [ring of free action](/wiki/Ring_of_free_action "Ring of free action") protects against all forms of paralysis ("You momentarily stiffen.", "You stiffen momentarily.", or "You stiffen briefly."). The paralyze monster spell can be limited to one turn by having [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance").

You will likely encounter many thrown potions of paralysis throughout the game. In certain cases, such as when in crowded conditions on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane"), getting paralyzed for five turns can be deadly. The danger is so great that some players will even wish for a ring of free action if they have not found one by the time they reach the Astral Plane. If you have one, you should definitely wear it for [the Sanctum](/wiki/Moloch%27s_Sanctum "Moloch's Sanctum") and Astral Plane.

Most of the other causes of paralysis are easily preventable with good tactics. You can completely prevent paralysis from hitting floating eyes by not hitting them in melee unless you have [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection"). Gelatinous cubes generally paralyze you for a short enough time as to not be dangerous unless you are in a crowd, but you can kill them with missile attacks if you're worried. Shade attacks are blocked by [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation"), so wearing a good cloak will usually prevent them from being a hazard. Finally, don't quaff unidentified potions that might be paralysis ([price 300](/wiki/Price_identification "Price identification")).

## Monster paralysis

Monsters can also be paralyzed in NetHack, a prime example being when pets hit a [floating eye](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye"). You can wake them up with nonmagical or uncharged drums or horns. In the case of floating eyes, zapping a [wand of make invisible](/wiki/Wand_of_make_invisible "Wand of make invisible") at the eye can help prevent paralysis.

You can also throw potions of paralysis at monsters, or wield them and break the potion over their head, to paralyze them. Beware of the released vapors that may paralyze you, though; a ring of free action will protect you.

## Helplessness

A similar condition, **helplessness**, is caused by the following actions:

- [engraving](/wiki/Engraving "Engraving")
- reading a [cursed spellbook](/wiki/Cursed_spellbook "Cursed spellbook") (sometimes)
- [chatting](/wiki/Chat "Chat") with a [skeleton](/wiki/Skeleton "Skeleton")
- [fumbling](/wiki/Fumbling "Fumbling")
- [hurtling](/wiki/Hurtling "Hurtling") through the air by throwing something while [levitating](/wiki/Levitating "Levitating")
- [praying](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer"), although a successful prayer also renders you [invulnerable](/wiki/Invulnerability "Invulnerability") for its duration
- quaffing a [milky potion](/wiki/Milky_potion "Milky potion") and producing a ghost
- entering a deserted [temple](/wiki/Temple "Temple") and producing a ghost
- using a [crystal ball](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal ball")

This state is identical to paralysis except that it cannot be prevented by a [ring of free action](/wiki/Ring_of_free_action "Ring of free action") or any other means. However, all means of inducing this state require some deliberate action on the player's part, so the state is always avoidable.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 2405](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.0_Release/src/uhitm.c#L2405)

## See also

- [sleeping](/wiki/Sleeping "Sleeping")
- [meditating](/wiki/Meditating "Meditating")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.0. Click here for more information.](/images/d/d6/Nh360-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.0. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-360}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Paralysis

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Paralysis is a magically-induced inability to move. Depending on the length and cause, paralysis can be quite dangerous, as monsters may get many free turns. However, a pet that was right next to you as you sleep may be able to guard you and therefore save your life against attacking monsters.

Contents

  • 1 Causes
  • 2 Prevention
  • 3 Monster paralysis
  • 4 Helplessness
  • 5 References
  • 6 See also

Causes

  • Attacking a floating eye. If you can see it and your hit does not kill it, there is a 2/3 chance that you will be paralyzed for a large number of turns (usually d70).[1]
  • Attacking or being attacked by a gelatinous cube. This paralysis does not last as long.
  • Being attacked by a shade, ghoul, guardian naga or Yeenoghu. This attack is affected by magic cancellation.
  • Being hit by a thrown or wielded potion of paralysis. This will paralyze you for 1-5 turns.
  • Drinking a potion of paralysis. This will paralyze you for 13-46 turns depending on BUC.
  • Being attacked by the clerical spell paralyze.
  • Being hit by Magicbane (one of the random effects).

Prevention

Wearing a ring of free action protects against all forms of paralysis ("You momentarily stiffen.", "You stiffen momentarily.", or "You stiffen briefly."). The paralyze monster spell can be limited to one turn by having magic resistance.

You will likely encounter many thrown potions of paralysis throughout the game. In certain cases, such as when in crowded conditions on the Astral Plane, getting paralyzed for five turns can be deadly. The danger is so great that some players will even wish for a ring of free action if they have not found one by the time they reach the Astral Plane. If you have one, you should definitely wear it for the Sanctum and Astral Plane.

Most of the other causes of paralysis are easily preventable with good tactics. You can completely prevent paralysis from hitting floating eyes by not hitting them in melee unless you have reflection. Gelatinous cubes generally paralyze you for a short enough time as to not be dangerous unless you are in a crowd, but you can kill them with missile attacks if you're worried. Shade attacks are blocked by magic cancellation, so wearing a good cloak will usually prevent them from being a hazard. Finally, don't quaff unidentified potions that might be paralysis (price 300).

Monster paralysis

Monsters can also be paralyzed in NetHack, a prime example being when pets hit a floating eye. You can wake them up with nonmagical or uncharged drums or horns. In the case of floating eyes, zapping a wand of make invisible at the eye can help prevent paralysis.

You can also throw potions of paralysis at monsters, or wield them and break the potion over their head, to paralyze them. Beware of the released vapors that may paralyze you, though; a ring of free action will protect you.

Helplessness

A similar condition, helplessness, is caused by the following actions:

  • engraving
  • reading a cursed spellbook (sometimes)
  • chatting with a skeleton
  • fumbling
  • hurtling through the air by throwing something while levitating
  • praying, although a successful prayer also renders you invulnerable for its duration
  • quaffing a milky potion and producing a ghost
  • entering a deserted temple and producing a ghost
  • using a crystal ball

This state is identical to paralysis except that it cannot be prevented by a ring of free action or any other means. However, all means of inducing this state require some deliberate action on the player's part, so the state is always avoidable.

References

  1. ↑ src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.0, line 2405

See also

  • sleeping
  • meditating

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.6.0. Information on this page may be out of date.

rawPage:
'''Paralysis''' is a magically-induced inability to move. Depending on the length and cause, paralysis can be quite dangerous, as monsters may get many free turns. However, a [[pet]] that was right next to you as you sleep may be able to guard you and therefore save your life against attacking monsters.

== Causes ==
*Attacking a [[floating eye]]. If you can see it and your hit does not kill it, there is a 2/3 chance that you will be paralyzed for a large number of turns (usually d70).{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|2405|version=NetHack 3.6.0}}
*Attacking or being attacked by a [[gelatinous cube]]. This paralysis does not last as long.
*Being attacked by a [[shade]], [[ghoul]], [[guardian naga]] or [[Yeenoghu]]. This attack is affected by [[magic cancellation]].
*Being hit by a thrown or wielded [[potion of paralysis]]. This will paralyze you for 1-5 turns.
*Drinking a [[potion of paralysis]]. This will paralyze you for 13-46 turns depending on BUC.
*Being attacked by the [[monster spell #Clerical Spells|clerical spell]] [[Paralyze (monster spell)|paralyze]].
*Being hit by [[Magicbane]] (one of the random effects).

== Prevention ==
Wearing a [[ring of free action]] protects against all forms of paralysis ("You momentarily stiffen.", "You stiffen momentarily.", or "You stiffen briefly."). The paralyze monster spell can be limited to one turn by having [[magic resistance]].

You will likely encounter many thrown potions of paralysis throughout the game. In certain cases, such as when in crowded conditions on the [[Astral Plane]], getting paralyzed for five turns can be deadly. The danger is so great that some players will even wish for a ring of free action if they have not found one by the time they reach the Astral Plane. If you have one, you should definitely wear it for [[Moloch's Sanctum|the Sanctum]] and Astral Plane.

Most of the other causes of paralysis are easily preventable with good tactics. You can completely prevent paralysis from hitting floating eyes by not hitting them in melee unless you have [[reflection]]. Gelatinous cubes generally paralyze you for a short enough time as to not be dangerous unless you are in a crowd, but you can kill them with missile attacks if you're worried. Shade attacks are blocked by [[magic cancellation]], so wearing a good cloak will usually prevent them from being a hazard. Finally, don't quaff unidentified potions that might be paralysis ([[Price identification|price 300]]).

== Monster paralysis ==
Monsters can also be paralyzed in NetHack, a prime example being when pets hit a [[floating eye]]. You can wake them up with nonmagical or uncharged drums or horns. In the case of floating eyes, zapping a [[wand of make invisible]] at the eye can help prevent paralysis.

You can also throw potions of paralysis at monsters, or wield them and break the potion over their head, to paralyze them. Beware of the released vapors that may paralyze you, though; a ring of free action will protect you.

==Helplessness==
A similar condition, '''helplessness''', is caused by the following actions:
*[[engraving]]
*reading a [[cursed spellbook]] (sometimes)
*[[chat]]ting with a [[skeleton]]
*[[fumbling]]
*[[hurtling]] through the air by throwing something while [[levitating]]
*[[prayer|praying]], although a successful prayer also renders you [[invulnerability|invulnerable]] for its duration
*quaffing a [[milky potion]] and producing a ghost
*entering a deserted [[temple]] and producing a ghost
*using a [[crystal ball]]
This state is identical to paralysis except that it cannot be prevented by a [[ring of free action]] or any other means.  However, all means of inducing this state require some deliberate action on the player's part, so the state is always avoidable.
